entry.title: Implement correct bounds for ChromeOS touch selection magnifier.
entry.content:
The ChromeOS touch selection magnifier is one of the features being

added as part of a ChromeOS touch text editing redesign. See draft

design doc: go/cros-touch-text-editing (mainly the Magnifier section).



This CL sets the bounds for the touch selection magnifier according to

the magnifier specs in go/cros-tte-specs. These bounds are based on the

bounds of the caret or selection endpoint, rather than the position of

the user's finger (which was the placeholder approach initially used).



To get the bounds of the caret or selection endpoint, we add a method

GetFocusBound to TouchSelectionController. Here, the "focus" roughly

corresponds to the selection endpoint that is currently being moved,

or the caret if in insertion mode. We then update the magnifier from

OnSelectionEvent instead of OnDragUpdate from

TouchSelectionControllerClientAura, so that the magnifier can be shown

as soon as selection dragging begins.



Screen recording of magnifier bounds before (i.e. from OnDragUpdate

position. Notice that magnifier follows finger position, even if it is

outside the text):

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rBCwDv63NMva4qyaPOZTPWKa2R-MkFRk/view?usp=sharing



Screen recording of magnifier bounds after (i.e. from OnSelectionEvent

focus rect. Always follows caret/selection endpoint to make it easier to

see the caret, though the movement is a little less smooth than using

drag update positions):

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Z28Rv-Bee5QZI6BDjz0oCwoLYAGBrBXQ/view?usp=sharing



Bug: b:244116654, b:273613374

entry.title: Revert "Prerender: Add WPTs for prerendering for URLs with fragments"
entry.content:
This reverts commit e4a8214765c98b0791f183905dd7eeb63be499a1.



Reason for revert: This is causing failures on https://ci.chromium.org/p/chromium/builders/ci/mac12-arm64-rel-tests



Original change's description:

> Prerender: Add WPTs for prerendering for URLs with fragments

>

> This CL adds WPTs to test and clarify current behavior of speculation-

> rules triggered prerendering for URLs with fragments:

> - If each URL specified for prerender are not completely identical, it

> will be prerendered individually. Therefore, even if some URLs differ

> only in fragments, they will be prerendered separately.

> - The URL of the activated page should match the prerendering URL so

> that they should contain the same fragments.

>

entry.title: android: Surface control magnifier implementation
entry.content:
Contains the implementation of the surface control magnifier. It's still

all dead code in this CL. Plumbing will come later.



Java side creates SurfaceControl and attach it with

AttachedSurfaceControl.buildReparentTransaction. Java side is also

responsible for positioning the SurfaceControl when the magnifier moves.

Java creates a framework Magnifier object just to get information such

as size and rounded corner radius. All information passed to native is

in pixels where applicable.



Native side connects to viz and uses slim compositor, similar to

CompositorImpl. There is no special case handling though such as context

loss however; complexity is probably not necessary as magnifier is

destroyed immediately after user lifts finger. There is some duplication

from CompositorImpl but probably not enough to worth duplicating.



There are 3 layers:

* Root layer has the rounded corner

* Zoom layer applies the scale/zoom

* SurfaceLayer embeds the renderer surface, with a SetPosition translate

to what's visible in the magnifier.



There are a few differences from the framework magnifier

* Framework one reads back from the viz surface. This one only contains

content of the renderer surface control. This means the content

doesn't exactly match:

* * Framework one can contain the selection handle itself (part of

browser compositor). Though the handling being moved is is actually

hidden after it starts moving.

* * At edges (in partice, top edge only), framework one can readback the

omnibox snapshot. Surface control can get to the point where the

renderer surface no longer covers the entire magnifier viewport; set

the background color to transparent so that this part just shows

transparent, which isn't too bad.

* Framework one has a shadow around the magnifier which isn't

implemented.



Bug: 1399283

Change-Id: Ic529e318cd55f8e58a52a09eee212c588a6d7258

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4514123

Reviewed-by: Vasiliy Telezhnikov

entry.title: clipboard: Write images to the system clipboard as PNGs and TIFFs on Mac
entry.content:
Uses Mac's image APIs to encode a NSBitmapImageRep to PNG format.

Writing an image to the clipboard will now produce two separate

representations - a PNG and a TIFF. Most applications prefer to read a

PNG from the clipboard.



This matches the behavior on Windows, which writes both

a PNG and DIBV5 bitmap.



Note that this worsens the gap between when

navigator.clipboard.write()'s promise resolves and when the data

actually appears on the clipboard

entry.content:

keys. To fix this, we verify that the build is using the official

Google-internal file containing the official API keys for preloads

and dedupe to run. Otherwise there is no point to instantiate

the services, as any queries to the server with an invalid API

key will fail.

ServiceDisabledInTestsWhenTestModeIsOff was failing in both the

dedupe and preloads unit_tests. I've simply removed the test

because it's not exactly a feature that needs to be tested anyway.

entry.title: Use RenderFrameCreated for WebViewGuest name/transparency changes.
entry.content:
Currently, WebViewGuest uses WebContentsObserver::RenderViewReady()

(which calls its GuestReady() method) to update the guest's name and

transparency. RenderView-based observer methods are generally

deprecated and going away, and RenderViewReady may not be reliable

when more than one RenderViewHost is involved, e.g. with site

isolation or if we are recovering from a crash and going to a

different RenderViewHost. Replace the use of RenderViewReady() with

RenderFrameCreated() which should be more reliable.



This CL also adds a test to ensure that window.name propagation in

guests works correctly across navigations and crashes. The test

passes both before and after this CL; it just makes sure that we have

test coverage for paths modified by this CL.



This change is motivated by a handful of test failures involving

WebViewGuest::GuestReady() without the early commit optimization, via

--enable-features=SkipEarlyCommitPendingForCrashedFrame. This is

because without that optimization when recovering after a crash, the

RenderViewHost that generates the RenderViewReady signal is still

associated with the non-live current RFH, so

ExtensionWebContentsObserver::GetForWebContents() returns null for it,

and we crash trying to set the name. Instead, the name change should

go to the speculative RFH that's created for the navigation out of the

crashed webview. With the early commit optimization, this worked because that speculative RFH would be committed immediately, and the

navigation would proceed in that RFH being the guest's current RFH.

entry.title: Update closure-compiler to v20210906.0.0 with required changes
entry.content:
Context: As part of migrating to Trusted Types CSP for CrOS WebUIs, we

want sanitizeInnerHtml from

ash/webui/common/resources/parse_html_subset.js to mirror the behaviour

of sanitizeInnerHtml from ui/webui/resources/js/parse_html_subset.ts.



To do so is impossible currently as creating a policy with a multiple

argument `createHtml` is not available

(https://github.com/google/closure-compiler/issues/3848).



This CL updates closure compiler to version 20210906.0.0, the first

version with the fix applied.



Changes required to apply this update to the closure compiler:



chrome/browser/resources/chromeos/login/screens/common/error_message.js

=> changed to use rest parameter annotation

ui/file_manager/file_manager/common/js/error_counter.js

=> changed to use rest parameter annotation

ui/file_manager/file_manager/common/js/mock_entry.js

entry.title: [Read Anything]: Rebase tree eventing on top of AXEventGenerator
entry.content:
This change moves Read Anything from observing raw subtree and node

creations to higher level events.



Events coming from the ui/accessibility component via renderer web page

tree updates come in generated (AXEventGenerator) and non-generated

(AXEvent) form.



After this change:



- distllation is triggered much less frequently. On a small sample set,

we distill only once (previously we did so 11 times) for a 90%

savings. Since distillation costs up to a second (depending on page

size), this has a large impact.



- a safer (and more readable) pattern is established for mock

tests. Currently, EXPECT_CALL macros are used without a clear tie to

the code to which they pertain e.g. in SetUp + the beginning of

tests. Start to use VerifyAndClearExpectations for this purpose.



- tree observation is only made for the active tree (through

AXEventGenerator). Previously, all trees were being observed.



Bug: none

Test: cq and test modifications.



Change-Id: I16f693be057becd2dd937071a3b244cc755f3d89

entry.title: [omnibox][perf] Fix keyword mode when `kRedoCurrentMatch` is enabled.
entry.content:
Entering keyword mode appends the `fill_into_edit` of `CurrentMatch()`.



This is wrong, because the real current match could be unrelated to the

search engine selected. E.g., if the user typed 'g', they might get a

'github' suggestion with a 'google.com' keyword chip.



Besides, even if the suggestion and keyword hint matched, modifying the

user's input seemed uncalled for. Typing 'g' should result in

'Search google|' not 'Search google| a past search query'.



The change is guarded behind `kRedoCurrentMatch`, a somewhat unrelated

feature. But a) want to guard this change behind some feature since

there's a good chance of edge case bugs, and b) `kRedoCurrentMatch`

rewrites how `CurrentMatch()` works; it seems practical to verify this

change with the planned new behavior, rather than the

soon-to-be-replaced behavior.



Bug: 1442244, 806262, 1418490

Change-Id: Id6130a65b218831ac9d0bd4c061e8f5f9350f279

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4505096

entry.title: Revert "Small rewrite of EditingHandleView bound and visibility updates."
entry.content:
This reverts commit 257a65ea139fc7d520b665cbcd698cea9146daad.



Reason for revert: causes crbug/1443022



Original change's description:

> Small rewrite of EditingHandleView bound and visibility updates.

>

> Slightly rewrite TouchSelectionControllerImpl and EditingHandleView to

> clean up some of the handle updating logic. As well as removing some

> obsolete parts of the code, this should make it easier to do some

> planned updates to the quick menu spacing/padding (b/276674892).

>

> The changes should have minimal effect (if any) on visible behaviour. To

> summarise:

>

> 1. There's no need to call EditingHandleView::SetBoundInScreen if the

> handle is invisible since we will call SetBoundInScreen again before

> setting the handle as visible. Remove these unnecessary calls so that

> we can remove the is_visible parameter of SetBoundInScreen.

>

> 2. Change TouchSelectionControllerImpl::SetHandleBound to take a bool

> should_show_handle instead of a SelectionBound bound. Also rename

> it to UpdateHandle since it updates both the handle bound and

> the handle visibility.

>

> 3. Directly check handle visibility in GetQuickMenuAnchorRect instead of

> checking ShouldShowHandleFor. This should be fine to do since the

> selection bounds and handles are only updated in SelectionChanged,

> which also updates the handle visibility. This means we don't need to

> convert to client view coordinates in GetQuickMenuAnchorRect.

>

> Still a bit more cleanup that could be done (mainly involving

> GetQuickMenuAnchorRect and ShouldShowHandleFor), might do in a followup.

>

> Bug: b:264825317

> Change-Id: If4f6411ffc91dba7d22abff7495329255fbff90c

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4402476

> Commit-Queue: Michelle Chen

> Reviewed-by: Thomas Lukaszewicz

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1126947}



Bug: 1443022, b:264825317

Change-Id: I5f7587c3ce094556725f15b97ad43f51a7060706

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4511353

entry.title: AbortSignal: Allow internal signals as source signals
entry.content:
NavigateEvent's internally constructed AbortSignal is exposed to

userland, which means it can be passed to AbortSignal.any(). This isn't

currently supported (it'll DCHECK), but is generally safe as long as

the signal isn't aborted in userland or made to follow other signals

later, which is the case. This will be made safer in follow-up CLs

when we make SignalAbort private and replace Follow with the composite

signal constructor.



Bug: 1323391

entry.title: Fix crash in SavedTabGroupBar buttons drag and drop.
entry.content:
The drag & drop session was showing the overflow menu when its button was hovered over, even if it would be empty (and its button was not visible). This caused the drop index calculations to come up with an index that was larger than the number of saved tab groups, index into children() with that index, which would cause the heap buffer overflow in the bug.



Added several checks to prevent this and similar issues:

- don't show the overflow menu when hovering over the invisible button

- don't show the overflow menu if there aren't enough saved groups for it to be non-empty

- CHECK that a calculated drop index is within the valid range

- CHECK that a drop index retrieved from drag_data_ is within the valid range



Also a couple of drive-by const and type fixes.



Bug: 1433304

Change-Id: Idadb403b17b3a8fb332115226a1ed38355ecdd57

Low-Coverage-Reason: Drag & Drop tests blocked on crbug.com/1432770

Reviewed-by: Darryl James

entry.title: css-multiple-display: Update serialization
entry.content:
This CL follows resolutions of

https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/5575.



* ParseDisplayMultipleKeywords() reorders and shortens keywords, but

does not change the specified keywords to legacy keywords.

It means

- "el.style.display = 'block flow'; el.style.display" returns 'block'.

- "el.style.display = 'flow-root inline'; el.style.display" returns

'inline flow-root', not 'inline-block'.



* Display::ApplyValue() uses ValidateDisplayKeywords()



Bug: https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/5575

Bug: https://github.com/mozilla/wg-decisions/issues/622

Bug: 995106

entry.title: Fix beforeunload prompt tests
entry.content:
Because of issue 1442624, we need to revert the feature

BeforeunloadEventCancelByPreventDefault. However, before we can do that,

we need to make sure no test depends on this behavior [1].



We are changing these tests that are using preventDefault to trigger

a beforeunload dialog. If feature is on, use event.preventDefault().

Else, will have to use a non-empty string as returnValue.



[1] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4452046

entry.title: [wptrunner] Improve `--no-headless` mode
entry.content:
* Do not use Xvfb when `--no-headless` is provided. Assume the user is

providing a real X environment, which allows the user to interact with

a paused Chrome instance [1] and use wptrunner's built-in testharness

results viewer. (Unfortunately, `content_shell --run-web-tests`

doesn't support this.)

* Default to 1 worker for `--no-headless` mode to avoid window spam.

* Do not force `--no-pause-after-test` and let [2] decide instead.



[1]: https://screenshot.googleplex.com/7nBnvLoDswSnboL

[2]: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/bf4540b/tools/wptrunner/wptrunner/wptrunner.py#L148-L162



Bug: 1440021, 1426296

Test: ./run_wpt_tests.py -t Default badging --no-headless

Test: Repeat above with `--product=chrome --pause-after-test`

entry.title: Implement two-value syntax of font-size-adjust
entry.content:
This change implements the two-value syntax of font-size-adjust

specified in the CSS Fonts Module Level 5 [1]. Four new font metrics:

ex-height, cap-height ch-width, and ic-width, are added, which clarify

what font metric the given value is for.



This change does not handle the CSS animation support, 'ic-height',

and 'from-font'. Follow-up patches will cover them.

(Pass, but not Windows)

(Pass, but not Linux and Windows)

(Partial Pass, the expected result updated)

entry.title: [DIPS] Implementing max redirect chain length.
entry.content:
Client redirect loops can cause the redirect chain to grow without bound. We need to limit the size of DIPSRedirectContext, while also reporting partial redirect chains to the best of our ability. This CL adds trimming from the front of the redirect chain when it exceeds capacity, and commits the trimmed redirects to metrics and to the DIPS db.



This CL includes a change to the UKM schema which requires a separate approval process. I'll wait on that before submitting this change, just sending out for early review.

entry.title: Remove IsCrosapiInterfaceAvailable() functions and use IsSupported()
entry.content:
This CL adds a new function IsSupported()

and replaces all of the following functions with it:

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsAccountManagerAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsBrowserCdmFactoryAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsMediaSessionAudioFocusAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsMediaSessionAudioFocusDebugAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsMediaSessionAudioFocusDebugAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsMetricsReportingAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsMultiCaptureServiceAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsSmartReaderClientAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsSensorHalClientAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsVideoCaptureDeviceFactoryAvailable()

- chromeos::LacrosService::IsStableVideoDecoderFactoryAvailable()



This CL changes the way to check whether some particular interface is

supported by ash-chrome. IsSupported() checks whether

GetInterfaceVersion() returns a non-negative number at

runtime. Previously, above functions were comparing the result of

CrosapiVersion() with the minimum crosapi version for each interface.

However, that way is possibly unreliable because some interfaces might

be removed in the future versions. Thus, it would be better to check at

runtime using GetInterfaceVersion().

entry.title: Reintroduce log and env_logger crates
entry.content:
These crates were previously reviewed and added by crrev.com/c/3321895



log is a useful part of the Rust ecosystem: it is a thin facade that

provides lightweight logging macros paired with a defined interface

for logging backends to provide.



log can be used by libraries: there is a no-op backend by default that

efficiently discards messages, and end applications can set a logging

implementation that all lib's messages will go to.



This CL adds log as a testonly dependency. In the future, we should

strongly consider adopting it in first-party code: a log backend that

simply forwards to the C++ logging implementation would be easy to add

to first-party binaries. This is the best of both worlds: we get the

standard logging interface used in the wider Rust community, while

also retaining consistency with C++ code.



env_logger is a simple log backend to be used in testonly code

(including dev tools). It is useful for Rust-only binaries.



libc is updated to meet new dependency requirements. This dep is only

used transitively by test-only libraries.



Bug: None

entry.title: Remove LazyImageHelper::Eligibility and simplify code
entry.content:
LazyImageHelper::DetermineEligibilityAndTrackVisibilityMetrics had

leftover support for multiple types of eligibility from when there was

both developer as well as automatic lazy loading. This patch removes

LazyImageHelper::Eligibility and splits the eligibility function into

ShouldDeferImageLoad and StartMonitoringVisibilityMetrics. In a

followup patch, LazyImageHelper will be removed.



There is a minor metrics change with this patch when the lazy load

setting is disabled, which is rare. Previously, we would record

Blink.VisibleBeforeLoaded.LazyLoadImages.{Above, Below}TheFold2

metrics when the lazy loading setting was disabled, but now we do not.

The new behavior matches the metric description.

entry.title: [scroll-start] Implement parsing for scroll-start longhands
entry.content:
scroll-start is currently part of the scroll-snap-2 spec[1].



scroll-start allows a scroller's starting position to be specified via

CSS but takes lower priority than relevant scroll-snap-* properties.



This CL implements parsing for the longhand attributes. A follow-up CL

will parse the shorthand, "scroll-start".



[1] https://drafts.csswg.org/css-scroll-snap-2/#scroll-start



Bug: 1439807

entry.title: media/gpu/v4l2: Refactor codec profile enumeration logic
entry.content:
This CL takes the file-static V4L2ProfileToVideoCodecProfile() and

V4L2Device::V4L2PixFmtToVideoCodecProfiles() to v4l2_utils, so it

can be used by e.g. V4L2StatefulVideoDecoder.



In the process, V4L2PixFmtToVideoCodecProfiles() is renamed and

greatly simplified, pivoting from the current switch-case + static

lambda, to a two maps solution (kV4L2CodecPixFmtToProfileCID and

kDefaultVideoCodecProfilesForProfileCID). (I could have first modified

the methods in place and then take them out in a subsequent CL but

given that the scope of the changes is very limited, I thought it

OK to put up what I ended up with).



Note how Enumerate...() has a base::RepeatingCallback() for the

ioctl call. This is fine because V4L2Device is ref-counted, and

will make it easy to inject a stand-along ioctl() too.



Verified via new test case on hana and trogdor.



Bug: b:279980150

entry.title: Use the current cursor location when hiding
entry.content:
Right now we have two interface SetCursor and MoveCursor. MoveCursor

would move the cursor while SetCursor would both move and set the

cursor image. When hiding the cursor, SetCursor is called and the

cursor is moved to (0,0) and the bitmap is set to empty. Moving it to

(0,0) can cause the cursor mistakenly show up in the top-left corner

in some circumstances (see b/280517949 and b/207087379). Moving to

(0,0) is not necessary and we can only set the empty bitmap when

hiding the cursor.



This CL changes the `point` argument of SetCursor to be optional,

and DrmWindow::SetCursor would only update the cursor image when

there is no location update. This could fix the wrong cursor issue

caused by DRM calls unsynchronized with page flips, and also save

one DRM_IOCTL than the current approach when hiding the cursor.



BUG=b:280517949, b:207087379

entry.title: Fix TestIncentiveBeforeEolDate
entry.content:
The TestIncentiveBeforeEolDate test was broken with crrev.com/c/4363231,

which changed the eol_incentive_util to use profile->GetCreationTime().

This caused the profile creation time to be set to the current date.

Because the profile creation time must be more than 6 months for the eol

incentive to show, this broke the test once May 2023 began, because the

current date used by the test is within 6 months of November 2023 (the

date used by the failing test).



Fix this test by setting the profile creation time to a date

which is at least 6 months before the current time (February 1 2023).



Bug=b:280975476

entry.title: Increase canvas resource recycling capacity
entry.content:
CanvasResourceProvider is occasionally starved of resources during

normal operation due to a race between commit completion and the

beginning of the next frame. When the task order is inverted, the

resource provider may run out of cached resources, causing it to

synchronously create new SharedImages.



The stochasticity of the race was causing the MotionMark Images score

to be particularly noisy. This CL implements a short term solution

which is to increase the max cached resources to 3 (from 2). Longer

term, it would be best to implement a resource manager that can

increase and reduce cache capacity adaptively and pool resources

between different canvases in order to degrade performance more

gracefully when capacity is exceeded.



Bug: 1435066

Change-Id: I8e814e3d62349715f923e2985d40cf9424ff3dea

entry.title: ozone/wayland: Don't request empty window bounds from compositor
entry.content:
If WaylandWindow::Initialize() is called with no specific bounds set, we

currently use default bounds of (0,0 0x0). This can happen in tests, but

also in some edge cases in production (see linked bug).



Also, shrinking the window bounds by the decoration insets in

WaylandToplevelWindow::SetWindowGeometry() might result in empty bounds.



Empty bounds are problematic because requesting them using

xdg_toplevel.set_window_geometry() will result in a protocol error. The

specification for this request says:

"The width and height of the effective window geometry must be greater

than zero. Setting an invalid size will raise an invalid_size error."



To prevent this error, we change the default bounds during

initialization to (0,0 1x1), and make sure that width and height are at

least 1 after applying decoration inset. We also add a CHECK to ensure

we crash where we would previously request an invalid window geometry

from the compositor. This gives us a more useful stack trace, should we

ever run into this problem again.



Bug: 1435478

entry.title: [Shopping Service] Add metric for recording product info js execution time
entry.content:
This patch adds a metric that records the ms execution time of the

javascript run by the shopping service to extract on-page product

info. The metric is only recorded if the execution is successful and

is recorded at the browser layer rather than in-javascript time. This

means the metric also includes the time to compile and do the prep

work before the script is actually run on the page.

entry.title: Remove PercentMissedDeadlineFrames
entry.content:
This metric was based on v1 smoothness metrics. These have known

accuracy issues. The implementation also has issues with variable

frame rates.



This caused excessive alerting in the OverrideThrottledFrameRateParams

finch study. Tracked in crbug.com/1382139



We also want to remove all the v1 paths. Tracked in crbug.com/1355477



The last remaining Finch IntelVpSuperResolution no longer requires it

either.



So we are removing the metric. We will maintain coverage via

CompositorLatency.Type

entry.title: Set proper value of |is_overlay_candidate| for low latency canvas
entry.content:
It is possible for the gpu memory buffer to fail creation. In this

case the buffer for the low latency surface is not set for scanout

and cannot become an overlay. Thererfore we must propagate this

error and fail gracefully by exporting the resource with the flag

|is_overlay_candidate| set to false.

entry.title: Add process isolation for default OAC.
entry.content:
This CL adds a new feature, kOriginKeyedProcessesByDefault, which

when enabled together with kOriginAgentClusterDefaultEnable allows

default-isolated origins to be placed in origin-keyed processes.



After this CL (and with the above modes enabled), origins with no

explicit Origin-Agent-Cluster headers (i.e., the majority of cases) will

temporarily trigger global walks and be tracked by

ChildProcessSecurityPolicy, because such tracking currently happens for

all origin-keyed processes.



Restricting the tracking to cases with explicit headers (non-default

isolation cases) will be addressed in

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4439195.



Bug: 1421329

Change-Id: Ic7341865279182c722644872b391735abeba4125
